entry.title: A Breif Overview: Regular Expressions (in Linux)
entry.content:
If you’re like me, you learned regular expressions in Theory of Computation and quickly forgot about them. Regular expressions are a powerful tool on the command line and can save you copious amounts of time when searching for patterns.

A quick side note about regular expressions – they were first implemented by Ken Tompson in his editor QED. Later, he took this same idea and put it the linux editor ed. From this editor is where the linux command ‘grep’ was born. ‘g/re/p’ meant Global search for Regualr Expression and Print matching lines in ‘ed’.

There are two basic sets of regular expressions: basic and extended [these are both POSIX]. Most programs in linux use the basic regular expression type. Here’s a list of programs that use the basic format and extended format (taken from http://www.grymoire.com/Unix/Regular.html)

Basic: vi, sed, grep, csplit, dbx, dbxtool, more, ed, expr, lex, pg, nl, rdist
Extended: awk, nawk, egrep

Let’s get into some basic examples and the difference between extended and basic will become clear. ‘^’ – Match epsilon (empty string) from the end of the line ‘$’ – Match epsilon (empty string) at the end of the line ‘.’ – Match any one character ‘[a-m]’ – Match any character a through m lowercase ‘[^a-m]’ – Match any character that is not a through m lowercase ? – Match one occurance of * – Kleene Star [remember this from Theory of Computation?]. Match epsilon or arbitrarily many of preceding character or range. + – x{n} x{n,m} ‘|’
